Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides partial support for meetings of the Pacific Northwest Geometry Seminar (PNGS) to be held during 2013-2015 at Portland State University, Stanford University, the University of Oregon Eugene, and the University of Washington Seattle. The first meeting is on May 11-12, 2013 at Portland State University. Invited research talks by leading experts in differential geometry, geometric analysis, symplectic and contact geometry are complemented by discussion sessions in which the speakers and participants assess the state of various areas in geometry, and highlight open problems in these areas.

There are a number of very active researchers in geometry scattered throughout the various universities which are involved in the Pacific Northwest Geometry Seminar. These periodic meetings bring these researchers together for consultation, collaboration, and stimulation of new ideas. A significant number of research programs have been initiated as a result of interactions at these meetings. The PNGS is especially valuable for graduate students in geometry at the various participating universities which have small geometry groups. The PNGS meetings give these students an excellent opportunity to see the broader picture of research in geometry. The meetings are also very valuable for the growing number of geometers working at some of the smaller universities in the region, such as Pacific University, Lewis and Clark, Seattle University, and Idaho State.

More information can be found on the conference website located at www.math.washington.edu/~lee/PNGS

POR.DRECONTENT:
This report covers the period 04/01/2017 to 03/31/2018. During this meeting there was one PNGS session which held in UBC Vancouver, March 4-5, 2018.

Here is the schedulle of the session:

1. Richard Schoen (U.C. Irvine): The positive mass theorem revisited

2. Christine Breiner (Fordham University): Compactness theory for harmonic maps into metric spaces

3. Regina Rotman (University of Toronto): Lengths of periodic geodesics and related questions

4. Ovidiu Munteanu (University of Connecticut): Structure of four dimensional Ricci solitons

 5. André Neves (University of Chicago): Existence, Denseness, and Equidistribution of Minimal Hypersurfaces

6. Catherine Searle (Wichita State University): The maximal symmetry rank conjecture for non-negatively curved manifolds.

The abstacts are available on the web-page: 

https://sites.math.washington.edu/~lee/PNGS/2018-winter/

There were 38 registered participants of this session, 22 of them were Ph.D. students or Postdoral Fellows.  

The speakers were chosen to address the most interesting directions in contemporary geometry. Every speaker, being an expert in the field, gave a comprehensive review and prospectives relevant to the topic of the title. The participants asked many questions, and the talks followed by lively discussions over coffee breakes, joint lunches and dinners. This certainly provided the graduate students with more exposure to active mathematical research than would be possible within the structure of a single university.

There were discussed new ideas which enable young geometers to consult and possibly collaborate with the outside speakers. It also provided opportunities for frequent contacts between geometers working in related fields, which is especially important for small liberal arts colleges in the northwest. These schools have in recent years been hiring an increasing number of mathematicians interested in keeping an active research program going. The PNGS meeting plays a very important role in keeping such geometers in touch with active researchers and new ideas in their elds.

The PNGS organizers encouraged the participation of women and members of underrepresented minority groups whenever possible, and  we have also been successful in recruiting women speakers: there were three out of the six speakers. This certainly helped to keep a diverse and welcoming atmosphere during the meeting.
